title: New AI voice tool trained to copy British regional accents

comments.text:
Looking forward to it:

"AI, call for an ambulence"

"Hello, 999? It's all gone Pete Tong, mate. Me ol' mucker 'eres fallen down the apple and pears, best get round his manor quick before he buys the farm, innit."

My wife's NHS trust has started using an AI system to dictate patients letters/notes. Its managed to turn "oesophageal cancer" into "Australian cancer" and this has gone right down the line with no-one really flagging that this didn't make any sense.

if AI destroys us it'll be due to some idiocy like this not "Skynet"

"The company said its customers wanted more accurate regional representations."

Did they though? Really? I simply don't believe it. The cross over between people using AI and people for whom the preservation of regional accents is important must be minute. My Bristolian accent is vanishingly rare in my central Bristol office. Much more common on a building site but no one is using AI there.

replies.text: I could imagine someone who needed an artificial voice (Stephen Hawking for instance) wanting to sound as close to their real voice as possible. Thats the only positive aspect of this I can think of.

comments.text:
What'll it do with
Wey aye. Ye gannin doon the toon to see the match like?
What d ya mean Nurrrgh? Are you a mingin mackem? They are wick.
I bet they won’t get the subtle variations of the East Midlands accents right? We find the accent can vary from village to village!

replies.text: Very true me duck.

comments.text:

Get it to take on Geordie, real Geordie and not the softy telly version used in TV programmes.

replies.text: You never had a cup of beans man? :P

comments.text: I'd love to see this application tried with the NHS. How patients with strong regional accents try to communicate with medical staff where English is not their primary language is a recipe for disaster. Time for AI to make a positive contribution to our society.

comments.text: But will the AI Brummie be able to empty the bins?

To slightly misquote George Bernard Shaw,"It is impossible for one Brit to open their mouth without making some other Brit hate or despise them,". Well I guess AI has got a headstart on that one, as we already hate it, before it's even opened its mouth to imitate any regional accent.

title: The Rumble in the Jungle 40 years on, by those who witnessed it

comments.text:
What a brilliant piece this is -- perfectly balanced in tone and pace.

Well done and thanks!

Perhaps a mention too of the greatest every (boxing) commentary that accompanied the fight from Harry Carpenter. "... Oh, he's got him with a right hand! He's got him! Oh, you can't believe it – and he's doing his shuffle! And I don't think Foreman's going to get up ... he's trying to beat the count ... and he's out! Oh my God, he's won the title back at 32!

Given his genial 'friendly uncle' image these days I think most younger sports fans these days don't realize how menacing the 1974 George Foreman was, his right hand was a wrecking ball and I could well believe he genuinely wanted to kill someone in the ring. Poignant how the vanquished eventually found inner peace while the victor paid a heavy price for his years of bravery/toughness.

I don't like big mouths as a rule but Ali has to be the exception to the rule!

Greatest fight ever fought captured in the best boxing documentary ever made...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tasCLcSslj4

#4 Wainronny

The name Muhammed Ali will still be remembered - and respected - long after Mr Khan is collecting his Old Age Pension in his wheelchair.
Even now, a lot older and infirm, Muhammed Ali is an inspiration to young people throughout the world for his strength of character and humility.

@the Welsh Wizard
Ali took the draft-dodger accusations all the way to the Supreme Court, where he won. He wasn't a draft dodger; he asserted a valid religious exemption, and the result, according to the Supreme Court, was that the local draft board conspired against him to draft him anyway. The press was only too happy to drag down a successful African-American who spoke his mind.
What a commentator Harry was. What a testament to the man that we remember him just as much as the fight.

@ wainronny (4) "These chumps have nuffink on Amir king Khan innit blut"

Only just seen your comment....If it was sarcasm....TOP MAN
If not....the only thing Amir Khan is world champion at, is using his celebrity status to avoid prosecution from driving offences.
Sporting theatre at its greatest. Anyone who hasn't seen 'When We Were Kings' relly sjould. Stunning documentary of the event.
True legends of the ring. Sad to say we will never see the likes of these men again, the Golden age of boxing.
Ali was one of my idols when I was young.. he was an absolute genius, quickest brain ever in Boxing, I never saw anything as graceful in the ring as him... He was truly The Greatest

The greatest sporting event ever.Heavyweight boxers Ali, Frazier, Foreman and Norton were the biggest and best, world wide sport stars, who were bigger than any poiticaian, film or pop star . No one gave Ali a prayer to beat Forman, but Ali gave it probably his best ever fight,brave, tactics used in perfection, this was Ali had his very best. his finest hour!

No doubt that the early 70s were the peak of heavyweight boxing.

In my view the only challenger to that for boxing ability, larger than life personalities was the Hagler, Leonard, Duran, Hearns era some years later.
I saw that fight. It was electric!

This was possibly the last truly great era of heavyweight boxing, Tyson aside, with so many wonderful fighters. It was all about styles. Ali would have trouble with Norton who would then be easily disposed of by Foreman. Anyone claiming Ali didn't have heart should watch the Thrilla in Manila. Both men almost died in the ring that night. True legends. Today's posers would be outclassed by them all
#45 calling Tyson Fury a decent heavyweight says it all really, obviously you haven't got a clue.
Ali was the greatest and it will always be to his credit that he refused the draft. Big man

I still think Ali was the greatest but I was afraid for him before the Foreman fight. The young Foreman was the most astonishing fighting machine I've ever seen in a ring - including Tyson. It took the most intelligent ever heavyweight boxer to beat him.

Nice to read an eloquent, unbiased comment (wish i had said that)

title: England vs India: Shubman Gill and KL Rahul resist after Ben Stokes ton

title: Ben Stokes: England captain's bowling is back to its best

comments.text: He isn’t England’s greatest bowler, and he isn’t England’s batsman. He is in with a shout of being England’s greatest all-rounder and is in the running, given his impact on the game, of being England’s greatest captain. But what he is, without a shadow of any doubt, is England’s Greatest Match winner. His runs matter, his wickets matter. He is a force of nature and we are blessed to have him.

replies.text: He's certainly in the conversation for best best all rounder in England history and is without a doubt the best Captain.

comments.text: A good all rounder balances the side. In my lifetime of watching England we’ve had three players who could bat bowl and field. replies.text: Terrific comment,  well put my friend

comments.text: I don't always agree with Vaughan but I recall him saying, some time ago, that the country perhaps didn't appreciate how good Stokes was. I think we all do now. Legend. replies.text: Best captain in England history too. Great player.

comments.text:
My opinion at the start of this series was that Mr. Stokes was the highest quality bowler in the squad, a squad which did not include Mr. Archer.
My opinion now is that we have two very high quality bowlers returning to their best form after long battles with several injuries each.
A huge credit to both bowlers & also to the doctors, nurses, physios & coaches whom have aided in their recovery.
🙏

I also hope that Mr. Wood & Mr. Stone return to fitness.

title: England v India: Jasprit Bumrah was a unique team-mate - Cheteshwar Pujara columns

comments.text:

No histrionics when he gets a wicket. Pure class.

As an England fan I have to say I'm generally more relaxed when Bumrah's not bowling, but I am enjoying the contrasting approaches of him and Mo Siraj in this series.

Siraj looks and acts like a Viking beserker, particularly when adorned with warpaint (aka suncream). Bumrah, on the other hand, plays like he's taking a sip from a can of beer hidden behind the stumps after every delivery.

replies.text:
Taking a sip from a can of beer. A great line.
Perhaps it explains the 2 defeats India suffered when bumrah played.

comments.text: I will be at Old Trafford this week and really hope to see Bumrah bowl. I'm English, but currently he is my favourite cricketer - plays the game the right way.

replies.text: Bowled a 10 ball over at Jimmy Anderson in 2021 (by bowling no-balls on purpose) just to bowl extra bouncers at him. By all means bowl bouncers at tailenders, but bowling no-balls on purpose just to intimidate them is not ‘playing the game in the right way’.

comments.text: Cheteshwar Pujara has been brilliant as a pundit on TMS and this piece sums up his ability to really give an excellent player’s view of things. This series has been superb!

replies.text: Fair point, there's been some very successful unusual actions over the years. Holding and Marshall were the best I ever saw, Holding's action was so smooth it felt like he wasn't even having to try. I want to be is friend !!!

Jasprit (smiling assassin) Bumrah

title: County Championship: Somerset beat Durham inside two days

comments.text:
A good toss to win in very helpful overhead conditions probably won the match.
As a Somerset fan I am glad we won the toss and the match and I certainly prefer watching a game played on a result pitch than the flat wicket last time.
That said a 4 day match shouldn't finish at tea on the second day
I am sure the inspectors will have a look.
The ball shouldn't burst through the top on the first day.

replies.text: At last a well balanced and respectful comment

comments.text:
They thought they were playing T20 or getting ready for hundred - 190 good score for that…

What a joke cricket has become finish a Blast - quarter finals in Sept and then fit in couple championship games before hundred and the 50 over county games….

Worth noting that, on a pitch people here are describing as sub-standard, nearly 400 runs were scored at very close to 5 an over on day one. If both sides had their Championship heads on rather than being still stuck in T20 mode maybe the tumble of wickets would have been less?

I take much more satisfaction from a result like that, than I would Somerset preparing a road to bat on week in week out. Who wants to sit and watch a team hit 700/800 runs an innings, with little or no chance of a positive result.

replies.text: There are options between the two.

comments.text: 400 runs scored on the first day for 22 wickets lost which suggests that poor batting may have influenced the scores as well as the pitch. If the ECB want players to get experience of overseas conditions then a dry turner isn’t the worst option.
35 wickets in 157.1 overs with a Kookaburra ball. How short would the match have been with a proper ball?

Durham fan who also went on day 1. Durham batting has been sub par all season. Graham Clark and Ben Raine cannot be expected to come in and save the innings 8 times out of 10. That pitch was a bit of a joke, certainly didn’t cost us victory either way. Imagine what the game would have been with a dukes!

title: County Championship: Warwickshire chase down 393 to beat Worcestershire in thriller

comments.text: Gutted but never mind once a Pear 🍐 always a pear 🍐 we will keep the faith see you all at New Road  next week against Hampshire never mind well played Warwickshire see you in 2 seasons 🤞

replies.text: Cheers , still have the One sayers yet to come.

comments.text: The weather saved Worcestershire at New Road when Warks were denied a victory earlier this summer but not a rain cloud in sight today as Bears chased down 393 with ease.

Don't worry about it, they were giving it large all day like they were world beaters.

What a shame.

Amazing performance from the bears
Mouse Malik Webster Barney & Kai were magnificent a never to be repeated day of CC cricket

We all knew the forecast & today would be a batting day but it has to be done & doesn't take away from the immense performance by the bears
A game my beloved 🍐s should not have lost except for the gritty resolute of the Warwickshire batters.

Happily for her the first ball she saw bowled was hit for 6 by Brookes. Then followed some cagey cricket which she somehow enjoyed?? We were both amazed to find this evening that Bears had turned it round and won!

replies.text: You know how to show a young girl a good time! 😂 Wasn’t Cadbury World open?

comments.text: Brilliant and unexpected win Bears - keep it up for the rest of the season !
25 years and counting lol

comments.text:
Awful

You Bears!

title: County Championship: Essex beat Sussex by an innings and 39 runs

comments.text: Well done Essex. A much needed win (and points). Hopefully we can back it up with a home win next week.

replies.text: And thanks to Warks too for beating Worcester.

comments.text:
Excellent win, great to have Porter and Cook back, and to see Critchley play a big role too. Certainly makes the table look a bit better.

Credit to Sussex for preparing a decent pitch with something in it for everyone. One in the eye for the Somerset fans who insisted the only options were a five session match, or both teams scoring 600.

replies.text:
Taunton traditionally gets better to bat on days 3/4.
Just like when Somerset beat Essex. Started green and favoured the bowlers but got good enough to bat on that Som could chase over 300.
Just neither Som nor Durham especially batted well enough to get it that far.

comments.text: Essex seem to be putting some good form together at just the right time. It’s funny when you look at the table from a slightly different perspective, and notice how many teams are in danger. An interesting few weeks coming up. Good luck Essex.

England have gratuitously ruined the season for Cook, Cox, and Essex, keeping the pair dangling with neither a contract nor a match. Both should go to Australia, but Cook's bowling has not recovered yet. I hope to see them in the one-days.

replies.text: As much as I am a huge Cook fan, there is very little chance of him going to Australia this winter. Cox has more of a chance.

comments.text:
Much needed win for Essex.

Sorry to sussex your bowling attack was below par - and the Essex attack clicked , nice to see the spinners Harmy and Critch finish things off

title: Tour de France 2025 results: Tadej Pogacar set to seal title after Kaden Groves wins stage 20

comments.text: A fantastic presentation by the ITV4 team with expert analysis of this Classics stage. I have said before that it is a travesty that this great sport is now going to be hidden behind another paywall and that the enjoyment that ordinary folk get from the TdF is gone forever.  The wealth of knowledge that Gary Imlach and his team deliver is exceptional and the various historical sketches are class.

replies.text:
FREE TO AIR TOUR DE FRANCE:

If you want the Tour de France to be free to air (and designated a Category A event), please sign the Parliamentary petition below. If we can get this to 100,000 it will be debated in Parliament:

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/716157

comments.text:
Brillliant from Pogacar, Vingegaard and also Onley.
End of an era for free-to-air TV coverage. Phil Liggett, Paul Sherwen, Gary Imlach & Ned Boulting. It has been amazing to watch, thank you.

replies.text: Reading Ned’s new book on cycling and the Tour at the moment. Great read of course but he does talk about the end of the ITV contract early on in the book and, though he’s pretty stoical about it, reading between the lines you can tell he’s heartbroken. As are many of us on here. Last day tomorrow and they should give each of the ITV presenters a special coloured jersey as a thank you.

comments.text:
Thank you Lloyds for your sponsorship.

Yep…end of an era!

replies.text: And at the risk of sounding lightweight, stand up and take a bow RTF for the coverage which at times (weather permitting!) is a love-letter to the French countryside.

Chapeau Kaden Groves on his first TdF stage win to go with the seven he has won at the Vuelta and the two at the Giro. comments.text:
Good ride from Groves. Cracked the whip and demonstrated that on such a stage, the break bickering amongst itself and fragmenting as it did will rarely produce a bunch sprint at the end. If you want it, just launch one.

Excellent tour, both riders and route.

replies.text:
Good emotional post race interview too.

Think he was feeling it a bit with Jasper and Mathieu both out.

comments.text:
Brilliant Tour De France.
The Ventoux stage was bike racing at its best.

replies.text:
Give Ben Healy the Tour combativity award, even though he was riding GC for like half of it.

For the 3 stages he went full Thomas De Gendt on.

comments.text: Pogacar confirmed he is carrying a cold so he cant wait to get to Paris. UAE/Visma controlled matters after the breakaway eventually formed. No love lost with Jorgenson and Wellens and they killed any opportunity of either winning with the bickering between both of them which has been present all tour. Ivan Romeo had a horrible fall and looked beaten up at the finish line. I hope he gets to Paris.

Well done Kaden Groves on winning in the Jura and winning a stage in each of the 3 Grand Tours. Awful crash took out Romeo and Gregoire (hope they make Paris).
Chappeau to Tadej Pogacar, 4th Tour win.

Ouch - I wonder what unit of measurement would be required to measure how long one of those hard men footballers would be rolling about after a crash like that!

Anyhoo what a chaotic day and well done Good Guy Groves - must look out for a femme version of Alpecin to celebrate.

Bit worried when Onley / Gall got distanced early doors but all good.

replies.text:
Puck Pieterse is in the Fenix - Deceuninck team.

She won't win overall but she might win a stage and she is the happiest rider in the world.

title: Luke Littler nine-darter helps him into World Matchplay Darts final

comments.text: If this game isn’t a hint that Josh Rock should be in next years Premier League then idk what is, pure brilliance and entertainment from both of them tonight great watch all round. Credit to Clayton and Wade as well they also played a fantastic match.

comments.text: Great night of darts..... Well done to all 4 players. At 24 and 18 Josh Rock and Luke Littler put on a show that had everything. A 5-0 thumping in the first session, a 9 dart leg, a 170 check out and a fight back victory. Brilliant

Both phenomenal players but Littler seems to have that rare ability that only comes around every few generations

He’s genuinely up there with Zidane, Viv Richards, Nadal, he’s one of the most naturally gifted sportsman in history and he’s 18 years old it’s insane

title: Euro 2025 final - England v Spain: What makes Lionesses manager Sarina Wiegman so successful?

comments.text:
Four major tournament finals, in a row, winning two, with two different teams, speaks for itself.

Anyone saying different is clueless.

replies.text: There is a great deal of misogyny at play here and this comment is coming from a man. If you can't be considered to be great at your chosen profession having reached five consecutive major finals with two teams then I'm not sure what qualifies irrespective of gender!

comments.text: With the number of finals/trophies she has as manager it cannot come down to just luck - one tournament, yes, but not that many....five finals in a row!!! She clearly knows something about the game, her players and how to get the best from them.

replies.text: She knows that the rest of the opposition are rubbish 👍

comments.text: I read somewhere that the manager and probably players have nailed on honours gongs after this. My mum is 87, she spent 55 years a sister in the NHS. She told us stories about amazing doctors, nurses, families and patients. Here we see these characters being honoured for 3 weeks of kicking a ball around. Its mind numbing. At least giving these things for such triviality gives them no value now.

replies.text: crumbs, and with respect, these women on that football field cannot be compared with your mum. Or any of the tireless people who work in our NHS.What the women footballers are doing is inspiring a generation of young women and girls to believe in themselves and to aspire to be strong physical joyful people. It is not just a silly . game of football. These messages matter to millions.

comments.text: She keeps all of her players motivated. Many coaches fail to do this. From subs to 1st team players.

replies.text: If all the players were motivated why did Mary Earps retire a few days before the squad was announced?

comments.text:
Experience. That's what makes her so good. She's an international football specialist and you can see in pressers how single minded and knowledgeable she is. She's calm, driven and takes tough decisions, like with Hannah Hampton/Mary Earps.

But she's great at spotting talent and bringing it into the squad, like with Hannah and with Michelle Agyemang despite her very limited league appearances.

replies.text: and will she play Agyemang and Kelly from the start or again late in second half ?.  be aggressive and play them from the start and attack Spain to close them down, if not and spain gain freedom and momentum Spain will win comfortably from evidence of all other england games in this euro.  She and England have had much good fortune and bounce of the ball. very fortunate to have reached the final.

comments.text:
So far, the women's game seems to be free of the shenanigans of the Premier League.

Hope it stays that way.

replies.text: Hmm in general I agree but Spain and Italy seem to model themselves on their male counterparts. Expecting some shenanigans from Spain later. Shame because they are good enough to win without them.

comments.text: To be fair there’s only ever a few teams that can compete at this level England being one of them, they have got lucky in this tournament, after watching the worst penalty shoot out ever, the standard is still mediocre - I love football and will watch all sorts Grass Roots, Amateur and Woman’s football some good stuff being played but lacking in several areas.

replies.text: The skills levels is low, as revealed by that farcical penalty shoot-out

comments.text: When she makes substitutions that have seemed obvious for 20 minutes, and then the substitutes score - is that a sign of genius timing, or just good luck? No axe to grind, I genuinely don't know.

replies.text: I think it's fair to say Russo works incredibly hard, so when Aggy and the other subs come on the defenders are already tired and softened up.

comments.text: If it is true that Earps left because she had fallen down the pecking order than shame on her. Wiegman has chosen the right person as the number one goalie. Earps should have been there as a backup

comments.text: I think the key phrase there is "calm demeanour on the sidelines". She obviously THINKS at every moment in a match, adapting as necessary. I personally prefer her style to coaches who run up and down the touchline (usually out of the box) ranting and raving. They are not in control of themselves or their team that way.

Most PL clubs don't win trophies.
Some PL clubs go through life always thinking they should.
That is the way of it.

replies.text: There's a difference between clubs that don't win trophies because they don't compete at the top end of the transfer market and clubs with the budget of Spurs. Two league cups in 34 seasons is abysmally poor for the investment made.

comments.text: If only balance sheets won trophies

replies.text: The did for City.  Unless authorities grow a pair.

comments.text: Interesting article. But Spurs haven’t won the league for 64 years, and counting. So it’s not just Levy. All the media noise about them is the equivalent of my Grandad telling me how good Old Carthusians were.

replies.text: I take your point but Spurs are a club steeped in history , perhaps more so than most others. They have a number of 'firsts' to their name , they are the club that has provided the most players to the England national team , and moving to today they have the finest training facilities anywhere in the World , and probably the best stadium in Europe.

comments.text:
My tuppence - Look at the progress of the club as a whole, get the foundations right, success will follow. Our foundations strong, pay off the ground. The nay sayers simply impatient - a consequence of good fortune under Potch home grown players etc.

Levy on for me 100% - patience

replies.text: Trouble is will still fail regularly to win anything. title: Tottenham's John White and his son's search for lost superstar

comments.text:
The thumbs down to some of these posts is proof that there is ALWAYS one idiot.
I've lost my Dad, miss him every single day, cannot imagine having not known him though. God bless you Rob, he would have been so proud of you🙏🏻

replies.text: Agreed...some folk just take pure pleasure in sowing misery and should hang their heads in shame...a sad story of a talented young man..

comments.text:
"There is still a kid in me that wants to know the simple stuff: what he smelt like and sounded like, a bit more about him, rather than this persona. That is the eternal frustration."

This hits quite strongly. I think there are people who want this even when their father's still alive.

replies.text: What`s with the down arrow? Some strange people around...

comments.text: My dad often talked about John White, what a great player he was and how he isn’t talked about enough as a former great player. Thanks for the article 👍

replies.text: Same here, my dad used to talk about him. Referenced him as the unsung hero, possibly the greatest player in lifetime.

comments.text: Superbly written article.

replies.text: This post has been removed.

comments.text: A true Spurs legend. Thank you for telling his story

One of the saddest sports stories.
I was 10 in '64 and only just started to be taken to Spurs home games.
I was a junior golfer at Crews Hill in the 90s. The older members were very cautious when a lightning storm came in during one Sunday competition and I remember being told the story about John White.

Remember him scoring direct from a corner against Fulham. A true great who we will not forget.

Shock and sadness felt on that day by all fans.
Thanks for the memories.........

replies.text: I saw that too. He was a fantastic player.

comments.text:
Interesting and poignant

Familiar with the likes of Blanchflower, Mackay, Greavesy but I'd never heard of John White before.

Amidst all the gossip and rumour, no substance articles we occasionally get educational articles like this. Well done

replies.text: Agreed.

comments.text: Bless you Rob.  That’s a really moving story about your dad.  It must have been difficult growing up and trying to live up to a perceived perfection.  It must then have been a relief to realise that your dad was human after all.  It sounds as though it has been a lifetimes work.  Love to you.  Liverpool fan.

A moving story. One that just shows how life can end so suddenly and unexpected. So when play is suspended in any sport due to the chance of lightning, those who decry the decision should be made to read the story.

replies.text: Golfers are particularly vulnerable as they are quite often in the open with basically 14 lightning rods near by, I was always told to get away from your clubs and never shelter under a tree if caught in a storm. Probably because of stories like this

comments.text: One of the greatest players I have ever seen live, absolutely brilliant, never got the plaudits he should have had but was a treasured member of the great Spurs - we loved him.

Watching Netherlands play on Tuesday, Schouten reminded me of John White.  Fair, slim, just ghosted around, very graceful.  John White was a very fine player, I couldn't believe it when I heard how he had died.

A great player - saw him play at White Heart Lane and Stamford Bridge and as a 12 year old remember being stunned by his death. Still got the programme from his memorial match, Spurs (with John’s brother a guest in the team) v Scotland XI.

Moving and well written article. Like the Busby Babes there was so much more he would have achieved…..
I was 13 when John was killed. I sobbed my eyes out and to this day still do on the anniversary. So much talent taken away far too soon. If only……….

Scotland should have won the Euros in 1964, with John White a key player. They had wins over England in 62 63 64, Italy in 65 , drew 2-2 in Germany in 64 from 2 down and won 6-2 against eventual winners, Spain , in Madrid in 63. The only problem was that that they did not enter. Clueless SFA as always !
My Dad spoke about John but playing for our club Falkirk, said he was a fantastic player. I’ve read the book his son wrote which is really good and well worth a read, especially for Spurs fans.
Beautiful article, moved me to tears.

As a teenager and Spurs fan - I danced on the pitch the night we beat Sheffield Wednesday to win the league - I couldn't believe this had happened. He was a wonderful player, so gifted and talented. He would take a corner with his left foot and if it resulted in a corner kick on the other side, would run over and take it with his right foot. A truly superb player and a great loss to Spurs.
I’ve always had an interest in John White’s story, I was born on the afternoon of July 21 1964. Thank you

title: Lewis Hamilton at Ferrari: What has gone wrong so far? And is there optimism for the future?

comments.text: He’s on an upward trajectory, last 3 races out qualified Leclerc twice and 0.09 off in the other. comments.text: In summary, Hamilton, as with all the greats, was once a notch above everyone else. title: Monaco Grand Prix: Has F1's iconic race become boring?

comments.text: ..."become boring"? It's been boring for years, mate.

comments.text:
"The answer is not a straightforward yes or no."

It really is straightforward. It is totally boring. It's a cynical corporate parade of cars that dares to call itself a race. In the past, at least there was the jeopardy of someone hitting the barriers but they don't even push that hard now because the risk doesn't outweigh any benefit.

replies.text: I completely disagree. Across a race calendar you want a variety of tracks, and ones where overtaking is difficult reward exceptional qualifying performance. Any overtakes that happen tend to be more spectacular, and strategy becomes all-important.

replies.text: And miami isn't even worse?

replies.text: Not helped by the fact the cars are ugly hefty trucks these days, only possibility of seeing some racing is get the cars back to nimble light race crafts again and some wet weather. As much as the circuit is poor, it's not helped by the awful design of the modern F1 car.

comments.text: It’s not ‘become’ boring, it IS boring!

replies.text: The safety car could stay in front and win, it's been boring for decades!

replies.text: ANYONE referring to "procession" should find another hobby!  Ever since the driver orders scandal/fiasco, there has been an element of 'procession' in races!

comments.text: It's just a procession from start to finish and not a 'race' in any  sense of the word. Should have been dumped years ago.

comments.text:

comments.text: Really enjoyed the visit -- fabulous setup -- and getting a pint a walk from the course was possible! Can't say that everywhere! Fantastic mix of a keen town and world class course in harmony.

I enjoyed seeing the Open played without too many grandstands on nearly every hole. The course has its own very pleasant personalilty with so many greens with steep run offs . There are dozens of wonderful links courses in the British Isles but not many have the necessary acreage and transportation and accomodation needs to host a modern Open .I think the R and A have got a good mix.

For me, an Open will also be affected by the weather - Portrush is magnificent, but we didn't get to see its teeth because the weather was pretty decent. A bit of wind and rain to really test the players. I think you could tell that the crowd were really buying into the whole Open experience - not just the Rory factor, because the same in 2019 when Rory wasn't there for the final 2 rounds.

I think it's an excellent Open venue, but like all the others it needs the wind to blow. That makes shot selection harder and also helps dry out greens which are otherwise slower than the pros are used to.

I like to see a winning score of between 6 and 10 under, and a nice 20mph wind would have ensured that.

replies.text: Carnoustie usually gives a score like that even if the weather is good but the R&A are considering dropping it because it can't take as many fans as places like Portrush!

comments.text:
Portrush is like several other courses on the Open rota, in that the wind is its only defence against low scoring. While the weather on Saturday and Sunday was great for spectators and showcased the fabulous scenery, it didn’t make for particularly challenging conditions.

Ironically, if Jason Day had made the cut, he would have had a chance to enjoy the wonderful weather.

My best spectator experiences at Open venues have been at Royal Birkdale, Muirfield and Carnoustie.
But I am concerned with the reports from some, that Royal Portrush was overcrowded at times. I hope the R&A take notice.

replies.text: My guess is that they will do the same to other venues, find ways to cram in more spectators, to cash in on the huge demand (over 1 million applicants for the ballot this year).  Conversations re turnberry are also centring on increasing capacity.

comments.text:
Portrush, and pretty much the whole Irish coastline are stunning, links courses are pretty dependent on the weather though for a defence.
When was the last open where the ground was dry, the sky's were blue, dotted with the odd cloud but the westerly wind was a good 20mph gusting into the 30's?
Now it seems even when it's warm there's enough deluges to take the fire out of it.
And it’s only £425 a round. Priced for the overseas market.

replies.text: Well twelve years ago the Lions lost the second test, but to be fair, that contest was a proper contest and both squads had once in a generation star quality with the rugby legends they had in both squads. comments.text: Really surprised that both halfbacks have stayed in the starting side for Australia.

comments.text: Australia will be a seriously good team on Saturday, much better than last week. I wonder if the Lions have taken anything out of last week's game?

title: British and Irish Lions Top 10s: Controversial moments including Matt Dawson and Brian O'Driscoll

title: Tears of joy as Sean Lynn urges Wales players to 'believe'

comments.text: After a torid  time then to win in Australia…. Well done and congrats .

Clearly, things have picked up, so well done to him and the girls. No point getting carried away - not world beaters or anywhere near - but much better. Keep it up!

The defensive improvement, under Lynn, is the most noticeable IMO. Line speed, double tackles, positioning, fitness and a general belief in each other to do their job. Well done players. Well done Lynn.

A very encouraging performance and result. Some of the running lines, particularly from the full back were exquisite. And that the fitness has improved massively can only give confidence. A massive step in the right direction. Da iawn.

title: Australia v British and Irish Lions: Garry Ringrose decision shows concussion focus - Ugo Monye

comments.text: Nothing but respect for Ringrose in making this call. Hope he recovers well and plays in the third test. Top man.

comments.text: Fantastic tennis by Julian & Lloyd! Three grass titles in a row: Queens, Eastbourne and now Wimbledon (the first all GB pair to win in 84 years)!!!

comments.text: Congratulations to them, they’ve been on a roll and full of confidence, but they still had to delivery in front of a huge crowd and they did just that today.

What a great performance 2 real good doubles players and British doubles at the moment is so good so many good pairs

Many, many congratulations!
Generally a level above the others this past year, a great partnership. Thoroughly enjoyed watching them.
More success to come I’m sure.
Philip
Bath

comments.text: Well deserved. Had to work hard in all their games I watched but always seemed to have another gear when needed. Just very solid pairing. Also liked the idea of having it on before the Ladies Singles Final.
Great win!  And another Brit in the boys doubles final, playing with Lindsay Davenport’s son, Jagger! Excellent.

They were the best team in the tournament all the way through and deserved to be the first in 89 years

comments.text: Really pleased to see this. Well done. Interesting experiment to swap the timing with the singles finals.  Pros and cons. But who cares what time you play it if you’re a grand slam champion!

replies.text: No cons, great decision

comments.text: Missed it with the time difference but watched them at Queens. Their heartwarming post match interview speeches were the best I’ve heard, all round a great advert for British tennis and tennis as a whole.

replies.text: Will you be able to watch it on catch-up/iPlayer? It was a great match, albeit over in 2 sets.

comments.text: Some great news finally. Well done Gentlemen. Beautiful day with the 🌞 and now a British win at Wombledon.

Absolutely brilliant all through the grass season , well done guys . Great speeches at the end too . Classy from both pairs . Pel did party well considering he’s been playing in challengers and not on the main tour !
Great match played in the right spirit.
Glasspool was very classy in his speech acknowledging the other pair which is more than they managed to do and in my reckoning was much the better player but great acheivment by the two of them.
Congratulations gentlemen. Very well done and well deserved. Nice to see more British Champions at Wimbledon, alongside Gordon Reid and Alfie Hewitt.
Congratulations, terrific win and a really good year so far!

title: Wimbledon 2025: All Britons out of Wimbledon singles - Naomi Broady on what we learned

comments.text:
We learnt that teaching tennis is all about money. Parents who can afford to pay will see their mediocre children make it so far. Real natural talent is lost when the parents are no longer able to afford paying for lessons.

Tennis is littered with substandard coaches milking parents hopes for their children.

replies.text: This 👆

comments.text: British Tennis has been on it's knees for years. It's a closed off sport with very little accessibility to training and proper facilities for those that aren't wealthy. We were going to run out of talented trust fund babies eventually, it was unsustainable.

replies.text: Rubbish

comments.text: Look at France - all their schools have playing fields and sports facilities as well as paid extra curricular sports activities. There is no sport because we have starved school of money.

replies.text: If that was the reason then where are all the top French tennis players?

comments.text: What did we learn? That the Hype rarely steps up & delivers. The media never learn, neither do the gullible ‘fans’ who hang on to every little word written..

replies.text: Don’t need to be totally negative about everything. I thought Raducanu, Norrie & Kartal had promising runs.

comments.text:
Just stop it. Seriously stop it.

Emma showed no such thing as being top 10 or ready to be such.

She beat a young kid and then someone whose ranking has plummeted into the 70s.

Nothing against her but articles like this don't help the perception she's overhyped.

replies.text: She almost beat the World number 1

comments.text:
What’s clear is armchair experts who probably only watch Wimbledon (and no other tennis each year) don’t know anything about the game.

There’s a reason why Draper is top 5 in the world - he’s actually very good. Of course he has a poor tournament, but he can certainly get to the latter stages (Alcaraz and Sinner a country mile ahead of everyone else except Djokovic).

replies.text:
Likewise, Radacanu showed that she has finally potentially settled and overcome her injuries and can climb into the top 10. She certainly has the talent to compete at the sharp end again

The number of moaners and whiners on here is incredible. Perhaps we should try to get that accredited as an Olympic sport - there’s top talent waiting to pick up medals posting relentlessly on the BBC forums.

comments.text: We learned that it costs a fortune to be part of a tennis club and to have coaching so most kids won’t ever go near the sport. Most municipal tennis courts are in disrepair and full of glass and slippy moss. To create superstars you need a broad based pyramid of players and in this country our base for tennis isn’t broad.

replies.text: Just plain wrong mate. My local club has a membership fee of £120 for a year - that’s £10 a month. It’s even less for juniors. Court access is free and group coaching is relatively inexpensive at c.£5 to£7 a session.

comments.text: We learned that the Brit commentators / experts are excruciatingly patronising when they speak about our players (with few exceptions). title: UK weather: Will we get another heatwave this summer?

title: Heatwave to ease in Europe holiday hotspots after Greece and Turkey surge above 40C

comments.text: Short lived heatwaves into the upper 30s or low 40s for a few days are very normal for the Mediterranean in mid summer. It happens pretty much every year. Its not news

Wildfire risk is high because it's been dry NOT because it's hot.  Most fires are caused by people either directly or indirectly, by accident or on purpose.  In nature the only time you would likely get a wildfire is if there was a lightening strike.  Stuff doesn't spontaneously combust at 45C.

replies.text: This is not unusual for this part of the world, it's just it's reported more these days.

comments.text: I wouldn't want to go to any of the places if it's 40C or above. What if the air con breaks where you're staying? Hell on earth.

replies.text: In hot countries even when it is 40c outside, it's nowhere near that inside. Even with the aircon off.
